comments.body: Looks like we might be missing law-checking for the `Eq` instance. Are there any others we aren't hitting?
@ceedubs Just added a test for that. I looked over the rest and I could not find one that wasn't in the hierarchy already but I'll be happy to add any extra ones if there are any missing.

If you look at the [code coverage diff](https://codecov.io/github/non/cats/compare/246512e0d813a7137f6c463779bef373bd126fec...4d00293c5ffc43fc2cb66cb3fb9fda94b4e6306c) it looks like the `Foldable` and `Coflatmap` instances aren't checked. The `Foldable` instance should be easy to check with something like [this](https://github.com/non/cats/blob/master/tests/src/test/scala/cats/tests/OneAndTests.scala#L31-L35) where you put only a `Foldable` but not a `Traverse` instance into the implicit scope. I don't think we have a handy helper for `Coflatmap`, so that might just require an explicit call to fetch the `Coflatmap` instance.

You've already done a lot with this PR. If you'd prefer, I'm happy to add these afterwards.

I thought `ComonadTests` covered `CoflatMap` and `TraverseTests` covers `Foldable`. Is that not the case?. I see those tests have hierarchical laws for those types and I see my tests output showing those instances getting tested (Unless is testing some other instances not the ones I provided).

@raulraja you are correct. However, you have defined separate `Traverse` and `Foldable` instances. So when you check `TraverseTests`, you are validating that your `Traverse` instance is law-abiding (including the `Foldable` laws), but the separate `Foldable` instance that you have defined isn't getting checked at all. It's a subtle issue that as of now requires a fair amount of boilerplate in our tests :(
Makes sense, I'll add tests for those two instances as well
